abstract.p: Walter Ghent letter on July 21 article holds public should be informed about annual cost of tax cuts, not 10-year cost

block.p: When I read that a proposed tax cut for married couples will cost a projected $292 billion over 10 years (news article, July 21), I wonder: When did we as a nation start making spending and tax decisions framed by their supposed effect over 10 years?

When I read that a proposed tax cut for married couples will cost a projected $292 billion over 10 years (news article, July 21), I wonder: When did we as a nation start making spending and tax decisions framed by their supposed effect over 10 years?

The effect of this is to make cuts seem bigger, spending more generous and political promises easier to fudge. I think we would be better served by knowing what a program or cut is going to cost next year compared with this year, not some mythical amount that a Congress three administrations from now will overturn anyway with its own 10-year plan.
